item.title: Boris Johnson: Humanity is reaching a turning point on climate change
item.description: World leaders must make major changes in four areas - "coal, cars, cash and trees", Boris Johnson says.

item.title: Energy firms' collapse hits 1.5 million customers
item.description: Several energy suppliers, such as Avro Energy and Green, have gone bust in recent weeks.

item.title: Covid debt: A baby, job loss - and now eviction
item.description: Tenants are being evicted due to rent arrears built up during the pandemic, an investigation finds.

item.title: Covid: Pandemic evictions, and US booster jabs approved
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Thursday morning.

item.title: Alex Salmond inquiry leaks being investigated by police
item.description: The leaks relate to the Scottish government's inquiry into harassment allegations against the former first minister.

item.title: 'Side-eying Chloe' Clem to sell iconic meme as NFT
item.description: The image of Chloe Clem could fetch her tens of thousands of dollars at auction.

item.title: Extremists using video-game chats to spread hate
item.description: Campaigners say including extremist narratives among everyday conversations can be a pathway to radicalisation.

item.title: Labour conference: Keir Starmer sets out what he stands for in essay
item.description: The Labour leader writes 11,500 words on how he would change the UK, ahead of his party conference.

item.title: Aukus pact: France and US seek to mend rift
item.description: The deal caused outrage in France, which lost a contract to build submarines for Australia.

item.title: Angry scenes at Haiti airport as deported migrants arrive
item.description: The US is flying migrants out of a Texas border town where 13,000 have gathered in makeshift camps.

item.title: Evergrande: Shares in crisis-hit firm jump as debt deadline looms
item.description: The debt-laden developer is due to make a $83.5m interest payment on an overseas bond on Thursday.

item.title: Food firms warn of panic-buying this Christmas
item.description: Gaps on supermarket shelves may become commonplace as labour shortages bite, industry bodies say.

item.title: Victorian ticket ledger found at March railway station
item.description: The luggage ledger dates back to April 1885, when the railway station opened.

item.title: The Papers: 'Winter of woe' and France rift deepens
item.description: The ongoing gas crisis and France's anger over a new UK-US-Australia military pact make the front pages.

item.title: Grim echoes of history in images of Haitians at US-Mexico border
item.description: Pictures of border officers rounding up black men have drawn comparisons to US slave patrols.

item.title: Covid-19: New allergic reactions to hair dye reported
item.description: Scientists at Imperial College London are now researching a link between Covid-19 and new allergies.

item.title: Angela Merkel: What will Germans miss about the chancellor?
item.description: BBC Europe editor Katya Adler takes a road trip to find out how Germans will remember their chancellor.

item.title: Saoirse Ronan: Macbeth and Lady Macbeth are like Kim and Kanye
item.description: The actress says Kim Kardashian has inspired the "uncharted territory" of her first UK stage role.

item.title: La Palma volcano lava engulfs homes and swimming pools
item.description: Molten rock from the erupting Cumbre Vieja volcano is destroying hundreds of buildings.

item.title: Is 'the worst cold ever' going around?
item.description: As more people mix again, the common cold is back - and leaving people floored.

item.title: Johnson and Biden: Contrasting characters do business
item.description: No major gaffes and progress on climate change on PM's US trip but a trade deal remains a distant prospect.

item.title: Angela Merkel: Four expert verdicts on a contested legacy
item.description: When the German chancellor steps down, how will history remember her? Four experts have their say.

item.title: 'Giving birth left me needing a colostomy bag'
item.description: Former triathlete Kayleigh Adams endured a fourth-degree tear that led to her needing a colostomy bag.

item.title: The edible insects coming to a supermarket near you
item.description: A number of firms are now farming locusts and mealworms for human consumption.

item.title: Changing China: Why Xi Jinping is leading a way back to socialism
item.description: China has not been very socialist for years, but the Communist Party looks set to change that.

item.title: Claims on pay, tax and the cost of living checked
item.description: Deputy prime minister Dominic Raab took Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday.

item.title: 'It's been a long time waiting' - everything you need to know about 43rd Ryder Cup
item.description: Three years after Europe regained the Ryder Cup in Paris, the US finally have their opportunity to avenge that thrashing in front of a partisan home crowd in Wisconsin.

item.title: West Ham knock out Man Utd to reach EFL Cup fourth round
item.description: West Ham gain revenge for Sunday's Premier League defeat by Manchester United by knocking their hosts out of the Carabao Cup at Old Trafford.

item.title: Australian PM Morrison says 'no special deals' for families of England's Ashes players
item.description: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison says there will be "no special deals" after Boris Johnson asks for families of England cricketers to be allowed to travel for the Ashes.

item.title: World Rugby to limit full-contact training to 15 minutes a week
item.description: Contact training is to be drastically reduced across rugby union in an attempt to prevent injuries and protect player welfare.

item.title: Afghanistan's female volleyball players tell of threats and fear
item.description: Afghan female volleyball players tell the BBC that one of the squad was killed last month.

item.title: Murray charges into last eight of Moselle Open
item.description: Andy Murray beats Canada's Vasek Pospisil to move into the quarter-finals of the Moselle Open in France.

item.title: Covid: How can missing five million be persuaded to have the jab?
item.description: Headlines have focused on teenagers and booster doses - but millions still haven't had a first jab.

item.title: Travel update: What are the new rules for holidays in Europe and the US?
item.description: Eight countries have now moved from the UK's red travel lists, to the less restrictive amber.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: People in England could be told to work from home once again through the autumn and winter.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Most 12 to 15-year-olds will be vaccinated at school, to help limit disruption to their education.

item.title: Is it safe to vaccinate our child? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about vaccinating 12-15 year-olds, the booster vaccine and other topics.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: Covid rules: What's in England's 'Winter Plan'?
item.description: Lockdown rules have changed across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: People are vaccinated - so why are there so many cases?
item.description: More than four out of five UK adults are now fully vaccinated, but daily case rates remain high.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: Significant numbers have had long-term problems after recovering from the original infection.

item.title: The torso in the Thames: A 20-year mystery
item.description: Twenty years ago, a young African boy was murdered and his torso was dumped in the Thames. It's the longest unsolved child murder case in the recent history of the Metropolitan Police.

item.title: Paul Rusesabagina: From Hotel Rwanda hero to convicted terrorist
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, who was portrayed in Hotel Rwanda, has gone from national hero to enemy of the state.

item.title: Fake Paralympians boss: 'I didn't know about cheating'
item.description: The man fined for sending non-disabled athletes to the Sydney Paralympics breaks his silence.

item.title: Muriel Gardiner: The heiress who saved countless lives
item.description: Muriel Gardiner's courage fighting fascism in Austria inspired an Oscar-winning film. Who was she?

item.title: Hushpuppi - the Instagram influencer and international fraudster
item.description: How Nigerian Ramon Abbas went from a romance scammer to a so-called "Billionaire Gucci Master".
